title: Energy conservation - particles move through 6V pd

content.question: A uniform electric field is present between two parallel plates, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, as represented by the equipotential lines shown in the figure. Particle <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and charge <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> is released from rest from Plate <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and travels in a straight line until it reaches Plate <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. Next, Particle <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of mass <math alttext="2 M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>M</mi></math> and the same charge <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> is released from rest from Plate <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>. Particle <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> also travels in a straight line until it reaches Plate <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. Which of the following correctly indicates whether the final speeds of the two particles are equal, and provides evidence or reasoning to support the claim?

choices.label: Yes, the speeds are equal. The particles experience the same force and therefore have the same acceleration.
Yes, the speeds are equal. The particles experience the same force over the same distance.

No, the speeds are not equal. The particles have different masses and therefore have different amounts of kinetic energy at Plate <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>.

No, the speeds are not equal. The particles have the same kinetic energy at Plate <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, but have different masses.

content.answer: No, the speeds are not equal. The particles have the same kinetic energy at Plate <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, but have different masses.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
